The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. div.p: THE SHORTER CATECHISM Agreed upon by The Reverend Aſſembly OF DIVINES AT WESTMINSTER.
CAMBRIDGE, Printed by Samuel Green, for Samuel Phillips in Boſton 1682.

div.head: The Shorter Catechiſm Agreed upon by the ASSEMBLY of DIVINES At Weſtminſter,
div.p: Queſt. WHat is the chief end of Man?
Anſw. Mans chief end is to glorifie God 1 Cor: 1 31. Rom 11.36., and fully to enjoy him for ever Pſal 73 24. to end▪ .
Q What Rule hath God given to direct us how we may glorifie & enjoy him?
Anſw. The Word of God which is contained in the Scriptures of the Old and New Teſtament 2 Tim. 3 16. Ephe. 2. •• ., is the only Rule to direct us how we may glorifie and enjoy him 1 Jo • . 1, 3, 4.
Qu. What do the Scriptures principally teach?
A. The Scriptures principally teach what man is to believe concerning God and what duty God requires of man 2 Tim. 1.3. and 10..
Qu. What is God?

A. God is a ſpirit John 4. • 4. Jo •
11 7, 8, 9., 〈…〉
Pſa. 90.2, and Unchangeable Ja • . 1.7, in his Being Exod. 3.14., Wiſdome Pſa
• 7. • 5., Power Rev. 4.8., Holineſs Rev. 15.4., Juſtice, Goodneſs and Truth Ex 34 6, 7..

p.hi: Q. Are there more Gods then one?

div.p: A. There is but one only the living and the true God Deut. 6.4. Jer. 10.10..

p.hi: Q. How many perſons are there in the God-head?

div.p:
A. There are three perſons in the Godhead; the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghoſt, and theſe three are one God; the ſame in ſubſtance, equal in power and glory John 5 〈…〉
▪

p.hi: Q. What are the Decrees of God,

div.p:
A. The Decrees of God are his eternal purpoſe, according to the counſel of his will, whereby for his own glory, he hath fore ordained whatſoever comes to paſs
〈1 paragraph〉
,

p.hi: Q. How doth God execute his Decrees

div.p: A. God executeth his Decrees in the works of Creation and providence.

p.hi: Q What is the work of Creation?

div.p:
A. The work of Creation is Gods makeing all things of nothing, by the word of his power, in the ſpace of ſix dayes, and all very good Gen
• . • . 〈…〉 1 • .3.
10 Q. How did God create man?

A. God created man male and female after his own Image in knowledg righteouſneſs and holineſs, with dominion over the creatures Gen.
• .26 27, 28. C •• . 3.10,

p.hi: Q What are Gods works of Providence?

div.p: A. Gods works of Providence are his moſt holy Pſal. 145.17., wiſe Pſal. 10 1 • ., and powerful, preſerving Heb. 1 3, and governing all • his Creatures, and all their actions Pſal. 102 19.,

p.hi: Q. what ſpecial act of Providence did God exerciſe toward man in the Eſtate wherin he was created?

div.p: A. When God had created man he entred into a Covenant of life with him upon condition of perfect obedience▪ forbidding him to eat of the tree of the knowledge of good and evil, upon pain of Death Gal. 3▪1.,

p.hi: Q. Did our firſt Parents continue in the Eſtate wherin they were created?

div.p:
A. Our firſt parents being left to the freedome of their own will fell from the Eſtate wherein they were created by ſinning againſt God Gen.
• . • . • , 8.,

p.hi: Q. What i • ſin,

div.p:
A. Sin is any want of conformity
unto, or tranſgreſſion of the Law of God 1 John 8.4. •
.
15 Qu What was the Sin whereby our firſt Parent • fell from the eſtate wherein they were created?
A. That Sin whereby our firſt Parents fell from the eſtate wherein they were created, was their eating the forbidden fruit. Gen. 36.1 • .
Q. Did all Mankind fall in Adams firſt Tranſgreſſion?

A The Covenant being made with Adam, not only for himſelf, but for his Poſteri • y, all mankind deſcending from him by ordinary generation, ſinned in him, and fell with him in his firſt tranſgreſſion Gen 1.16 17. Rom. 1 12. 1 Cor 15.2 • , •• ..
Q. Into what eſtate did the fall bring mankind?
A. The fall brought mankind into an eſtate of ſin and miſery Rom. 5.12..
Q. wherein conſiſts the ſinfulneſs of that eſtate whereinto man fell?

A. The ſinfulneſs of that eſtate whereinto man fell, conſiſts in the guilt of Adams firſt ſin, the want of original righteouſneſs, and the corruption of his whole nature, which is commonly
called original Sin, together with all actual Tranſgreſſions which proceed from it Rom. 5.12, 1 • . &
•
• 0 •• . • . Heb. 2.1, 2 3. Matth. 25 13..
Q. What is the miſery of that eſtate whereinto man fell?

A. All mankind by their fall loſt Communion with God Gen. 3.8 10.14., are under his wrath and curſe Ephe.
• .2.3. Gal. 3 1 • ., and ſo made liable to all miſeries in this life, and death it ſelf and to the pains of hell for ever Lam. 3.39. Rom. 5.23. Ma •
25.41, 46.
20 Q. Did God leave all mankind to periſh in the eſtate of ſin and miſery?

A. God haveing out of his meer good pleaſure from all eternity elected ſome to everlaſting life Eph. 2.4., did enter into a covenant of grace, to deliver them out of the eſtate of ſin and miſery, and to bring them into a ſtate of ſalvation by a Redeemer Rom. 3 • 20, 21▪ 22. Gal. 3.21.22.
Queſt. Who is the Redeemer of Gods Elect?

A. The only Redeemer of Gods Elect is the Lord Jeſus Chriſt 1 Tim.
• .56., who being the eternal Son of God, became man Jo •
11 4. Gal.
• 4., and ſo was, and continueth to be God and man in two diſtinct natures, Rom. 9.5. Luke 1.35. Col. 1.9. Heb. 7. • 4 and one Perſon forever,

p.hi: Q. How did Chriſt being the Son of God become man▪

div.p:
A. Chriſt the Son of God became man by taking to himſelf a true body Heb. 1. • 4, 26. & 10.5., and a reaſonable Soul Luke 1.27, 31, 35.4 •
Gal. 4.4. ▪ being conceived by the power of the holy Ghoſt, in the womb of the Virgin Mary, and born of her r, and yet without ſin Heb 3. • 5.,

p.hi: Qu. What Offices doth Chriſt execute as our Redeemer?

div.p:
A. Chriſt as our Redeemer executeth the Offices of a Prophet, o • a Prieſt, and of • King, both in his eſ • ate of Humiliation and Exaltation Acts 3.21, • 2. Heb 12.25 with 2 Cor 133. Heb. 5.5, 6, 7. & 7.25., Pſal: 2.6. Iſai. 9.6.7. Mark. 2. ••
Pſal. 2.8.11

p.hi: Q How doth Christ execute the Office of a Prophet?

div.p: A. Chriſt executeth the Office of a Prophet, in revealing to us by his word and Spirit the will of God for our Salvation Job. 1.18 1 Pet. 1.11, 12. Job 15. • 9..

p.hi: Q. How doth Chriſt execute the Off •• e of a Prieſt?

div.p:
A. Chriſt executeth the Office of a Prieſt in his once offering up of himſelf a ſacrifice to ſatisfie divine juſtice Heb 9.14, 9.,
and reconcile us to God Heb. 2. • ., and in making continual interceſſion for us Heb. 7.24, 25.,

p.hi: Q. How doth Chriſt execute the Office of a King?

div.p:
A. Chriſt executeth the Office of a King in ſubduing of us to himſelf Act. 15.14, 15, 16., in ruling Iſaia.
• 2.22., and defending us Io. 32.1.2., and in reſtraining and conquering, all his and our Enemies 1 Cor. 15.25 Pſal 10 3.,

p.hi: Q. Wherein did Chriſts Humiliation conſiſt?

div.p: A. Chriſts Humiliation conſiſted in his being born, and that in a low condition Luk. 2.7, made under the law Gal. 4. • ., undergoing the miſeries of this life Heb. 1 2 • 3. Iſai. 53.2, • ., the wrath of God Luk 22.44. Mat 17 19, and the curſed death of the Croſs Pſal. 2.8, in being buried 1 Cor. 15 3, 4, and continuing under the power of death for a time Act 2.24, 31..

p.hi: Q. Wherein conſiſts Chriſt Exaltaion?

div.p: A. Chriſts Exaltation conſiſteth in • is riſing again, from the dead on the 〈◊〉 third day 1 Cor. 1 • 4., and in aſcending up into • eaven Mark 16.19, in ſitting at the right hand 〈◊〉 God the Father Eph 1.22, and in coming to •• dge the world at the laſt day Acts 1.11. & 17. • 1.,

p.hi:
Q, How are we made partakers
of the Redemption purchaſed by Chriſt?

div.p: A. We are made partakers of the Redemption purchaſed by Chriſt, by the effectual application of it to us John 1.11. • 2., by his holy Spirit Tit. 3.5, 6.
30 Q. How doth the holy Spirit apply to us the Redemption purchaſed by Chriſt

A: The Spirit applyeth to us the Redemption purchaſed by Chriſt, by working faith in us Eph 1 13 14. John 6 2 • , 39. John
• .8., and thereby uniting us to Chriſt in our Effectual calling Eph 3.17 •
Cor 1.9..
Q. What is effectual calling?

A. Effectual calling is the work of Gods Spirit 2 T • m 1 9. 2 Theſ. 2 13.14., whereby convincing us of our ſin and miſery Act
• 37, inlightning our minds in the knowledge of Chriſt Acts 2 • 1 •
, and renewing our wills Ezek 36 26 27, he doth perſwade and enable us to embrace Jeſus Chriſt freely offered to us in the Goſpel Joh. 6 44 45.
Qu. What benefits do they that are Effectually called partake of in this life?

Anſw. They that are Effectually called, do in this life partake of Juſtification
〈1 paragraph〉
, Adoption
〈1 paragraph〉
, Sanctification, and the ſeveral benefits which in this life do either accompany or flow from there
〈1 paragraph〉
.
Q. What is Iuſtification?

A Juſtification is an act of Gods free grace, wherein he pardoneth all our ſins Rom. 3.24, 25. & 4.6, 7, 8., and accepteth us as righteous in his ſight 2 Cor. 5.19, 21., only for the righteouſneſs of Chriſt imputed to us Rom. 5.17, 18, 19., and received by Faith alone Gal. 2.1 Phil. 3.9..
Q: What is Adoption?
A. Adoption is an act of Gods free grace 1 Joh. 3.1., whereby we are received into the number, and have a right to all the priviledges of the Sons of God John 8 11. Rom· 8.17..
Q: What is Sanctification?

Anſw: Sanctification is the work of Gods free grace 2 Theſ. 2.3, wherby we are renewed in the whole man after the Image of God Eph. 4 23 24., Rom 6.3, 6. and are enabled more and more to dy unto ſin, and live unto rightouſneſs.
Q. What are the benefits that in this life do accompany or flow from juſtification, A • option and Sanctification?

A. The benefits which in this life do accompany or flow from juſtification, Adoption, and ſanctification, are aſſureance of Gods love, precept Conſcience Rom. 5 •• .5., joy in the holy Ghoſt Ro •
1.4.17., increaſe of grace 1 Joh. 3·1 •
, and perſeverance therin to the end 1 Pet. 1.5. 1 Pet. 4.18.,

p.hi: Q. what benefits do belivers receive from Chriſt at death,

div.p: A. The Soules of believers are at their death made perfect in holineſs Heb 12.23., and do immediatly paſs into glory 2 Cor 5.1.6.8. Phi • . 1.23 Luke 23.43., and their bodies being ſtill united to Chriſt 1 Theſ. 4.14., do reſt in their graves, till the Reſurrection Iſai. 57.2.,

p.hi: Q. What benefits do belivers receive from Chriſt at the Reſurrection.

div.p: A. At the Reſurrection believers being raiſed in glory 1 Cor 15 43., ſhall be openly acknowledged and acquitted in the day of Judgment Mat 25.23. & 1 • .31., and made perfectly bleſſed in full enjoying of God 1 John 3 2. 1 Theſ 13.12. to all Eternity 1 Cor. 4.17, 18.,

p.hi: Q what is the duty which God requireth of man,

div.p:
A. The duty w •••• God requireth of Man, is obedie • ce to his revealed will Mic
• .8 1 Sam
• 5.2 • .,

p.hi: Q What did God at firſt reveal to man as the Rule of his obedience?

div.p: A. The Rule which God at firſt revealed to man for his obedience, was the Moral law Rom 2 • .14, 15. & 10.5.,

p.hi: Q. Where is the Moral Law ſummarily comprehended?

div.p: A. The Moral Law is ſummarily comprehended in the ten Commandments De • . 10.4▪ ,

p.hi: Q What is the ſum of the ten Commandments?

div.p: A. The ſum of the ten Commandments is, to love the Lord our God with all our heart, with all our ſoul, with all our ſtrength, and with all our mind, and our Neghbour as our ſelves Ma • . 21.37. to 40.,

p.hi: Q. What is the Preface to the ten Commandments?

div.p:
A. The Preface to the ten Commandments is in theſe words, I am the Lord thy God which have brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the houſe of bondage.
Exod. 2 2.
Q. What doth the Preface to the ten Commandments teach us?

A. The Preface to the ten Commandments teacheth us, that becauſe God is the Lord, and our God and Redeemer, therefore we are bound to keep all his Commandments Luke 1.74, 75. 1 Pet. 1.1 •
• 0▪ ,
45 qu. which is the firſt Commandment,

A. The firſt Commandment is, Thou ſhalt have no other Gods before me
Exod. 20 •
,
qu. What is required in the firſt Commandment?

A. The firſt Commandment requireth
us to know and acknowledge God to be the only true God, and our God 1 Chron. 8.9. Deu. 26.17, and to wo • ſhip and glorifie him accordingly Mat. 4.10 Pſal.
• 9.1.,
Q. What is forbidden in the firſt Commandment?

A. The firſt Commandment forbiddeth the denying Pſ • l. 14 1., or not worſhipping and glorifying the true God as God Rom. 1.21., and our God Pſal. 81 10, 1 • ., and the giving that wo • ſhip and glory to any other, which is due to him alone Rom. 1. • 5, 16.,
Q. What are we eſpecially taught by theſe wor • s (before me) in the firſt Commandment?

A. Theſe words (before me) in the firſt Commandment teach us, that God who ſeeth all things, taketh notice of and is much displeaſed with the ſin of haveing any other God Ezek
• . • . to end. ,
Q. Wh • ch is the ſecond Commandment?

A. The ſecond Commandment is, Thou ſhalt not make unto thee any graven Image, or the likeneſs of any thing that is in Heaven above, or that is in the Earth beneath: or that is in the water under the Earth thou ſhalt not bow down thy ſelf
to them nor ſerve them, for I the Lord thy God am a jealous God, viſiting the iniquity of the Fathers upon the Children unto the third and fourth generation of them that hate me, and ſhewing mercy unto thouſands of them that • ove me & keep my Commandments Exod. 20. 4, 5, • ..
50 Q. What is required in the ſecond Commandment?

A. The ſecond Commandment requireth the receiving, obſerving, and keeping pure and entire all ſuch religious Worſhip and Ordinances as God hath appointed in his Word Deut.
•• 4, 6. Mat 28.20 Acts
• .4 •
,
Q. What is forbiden in the ſecond Commandment?

A, The ſecond Commandment forbiddeth the Worſhip of God by Images Deut.
•• 15, 19. Exod. 32.9 8., or any other way not appointed in his Word Deut. 1 • .31, 3 •
,
Q. What are the Reaſons annexed to the ſecond Commandment?

A. The Reaſons annexed to the ſecond Commandment are Gods Sovereignty over us Pſal. 6 • 2, 3, 6., his propriety in us Pſal. 4 • 11., and the zeal he hath to his own Worſhip Ex.
• 4.13, 14
Q, Which is the third Commandment?

A. The third Commandment is, Thou ſhalt not take the Name of the Lord thy God in vain, for the Lord will not hold him guiltleſs that taketh his Name in vain
Exod. 10,
Q. What is required in the third Commandment?

A, The third Commandment requireth the holy and reverent uſe of Gods Name Mat. 9.2 Deut. 2 • . •• ., Titles Pſal 68.4., Attributes Rev 1 • .13, 14., Ordinances Mal. 1.11 4., Words Pſal 1 • 38.1, 2., and Works Jo •
36.24.,
55 Q. What is forbidden in the third Commandment?

A: The third Commandment forbiddeth all profaining or abuſing of any thing whereby God makes himſelf known Mat. 1.6 7, 1 •
▪ ,

p.hi: Q What is the Reaſon annexed to the third Commandment?

div.p:
A. The Reaſon annexed to the third Commandment is that however the breakers of this Commandment may eſcape puniſhment from men,
•
Sa • .
• 1 • . yet the Lord our God will not ſuffer them to eſcape his righteous judgement,

p.hi: Qu. Which is the fourth Commandment?

div.p:
A. The fourth Commadment is,
Remember the Sabbath day to keep it holy Six dayes ſhalt thou labour, and do all thy work, but the ſeventh day is the Sabbath of the Lord thy God: i • it thou ſhalt not do any work, Thou, nor thy Son, nor thy Daughter, nor thy Man-ſerva • t, nor thy Mai • -ſervant, nor thy Cattle, nor the Stranger that is within thy ga • es: for in ſix dayes the Lord made Heaven and Earth, the S • a, and all that in them i • , and reſted the ſeventh day: wherefore the Lord bleſſed the Sabbath day and, • allow • d it
Exod. 20.8, 9, 10, 11..
Q What is required in the fourth Commandment?

A▪ The fourth Commandment requireth the keeping holy to God ſuch • et times as he hath appointed in his Word, expreſly one whole day in ſeven, to be a holy Sabbath to himſelf Deut.
•
▪ 12, 13, 14..
Q. Which day of the ſeven hath God appointed to be the weekly Sabbath?

A. From the Beginning of the world to the Reſurrection of Chriſt, God appointed the ſeventh day of the Week • o be the weekly Sabbath, and the firſt • ay of the Week ever ſince to co •
to the end of the world, which is the Chriſtian Sabbath A • t •
20.7. Exo. 20 8 10., Gen. 2.23 1 Cor. 6.1

p.hi: Q. How is the Sabbath to be ſanctified;

div.p:
A. The Sabbath is to be ſanctified by a holy reſting all that day k, even from ſuch worldly imployments and recreations as are lawfull on other dayes Ex 1 • . • 5▪ 39. Neh 19 15 21, and ſpending the whole time in the publick and private exerciſes of Gods worſhip L ••

20 7. Pſal. 92▪

div.p:
A. The fourth Commandment forbiddeth the omiſſion, or eareleſs performance of the duties re • uired Ezek. 2 • 18. Amos 8.5. Mal 1 15, and profaning the day by idleneſs Acts 10 7, 9., or doing that which is in it ſelf ſinfull Ezek. 23 38., or by unneceſſary thoughts, words, or works, about worldly imployments or Recreations Jer.
